dialogue_content.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: I'd love to hear about how you first learned the gears in clockmaking.

dialogue_content.original_text: It was in a small workshop in my hometown in Germany.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: I must have been around 14 or 15.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: My father was a clockmaker, and every day after school, I'd rush to his workshop.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: It sounds like a special bond with your father. What was it like working with him day after day?

dialogue_content.original_text: Each gear, each tick of the clock seemed to hold a story.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: My father had a quiet way of teaching—he'd often say, 'The clock will tell you what it needs if you listen closely.'
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: So when did things change for you in the clockmaking world?

dialogue_content.original_text: Things began to change when the Quartz Crisis came along.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: It was around the 1970s, and suddenly, these new quartz watches were everywhere.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: Many of us, traditional clockmakers, were worried.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: That must have been hard, seeing the world move in a direction that felt so different from your life's work.

dialogue_content.original_text: I remember having long discussions with fellow clockmakers.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: Some started incorporating quartz movements into their designs, but it never quite felt the same.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: I'd love to hear how you coped with those changes. Did you find a way to adapt?

dialogue_content.original_text: I focused more on repairing antique clocks, which kept the old art alive in some way.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: But it was a struggle, watching the younger generation gravitate toward the quartz watches and digital displays.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: It sounds like those were challenging times. How did you find a way to maintain your passion for clockmaking during that period?

dialogue_content.original_text: Well, as I mentioned, I turned to repairing antiques.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: I also began teaching younger enthusiasts who were interested in the traditional methods.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: So, what does your work look like nowadays, Hans? Are you still working with antique clocks?

dialogue_content.original_text: And every time I hear a clock chime again after being silent for so long, it feels like I've given it a second life.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: It sounds like those antique clocks have been a source of comfort for you. How do you feel when you're working on them now?

dialogue_content.original_text: Working on these old clocks brings me a deep sense of peace.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: That sounds truly fulfilling, Hans. It must be rewarding to preserve those stories and keep the art alive. Have you found that your perspective on time has changed over the years, especially as you've continued your work with these antique clocks?

dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
dialogue_content.original_text: Yes, my perspective on time has evolved quite a bit. When you're young, time seems infinite, doesn't it? But as I grew older, working with these clocks, I began to see time differently. Each clock, each tick, is a reminder of how fleeting moments are. These clocks have been around for generations, some longer than I've been alive, yet they keep on ticking, marking the passage of time. It's humbling. Standing in their presence, I often think about my own time, what's left, and how I choose to spend it. Working with them has taught me patience and the value of living in the moment. In a world that's always rushing, these clocks remind me to slow down and appreciate each tick.

dialogue_content.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: Before we finish, Hans, if you could share one final lesson or piece of wisdom from your years as a clockmaker, what would it be?

dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
dialogue_content.original_text: Ah, a final lesson... I'd say it's to appreciate the beauty in the small things and take the time to understand them. Life is much like a clock with its many gears—each small piece plays its part, and together, they create something extraordinary. It's easy to get caught up in the rush, but if you listen closely, much like my father used to say, 'The clock will tell you what it needs.' In those quiet moments, there's clarity. Treasure the details, the stories they hold, and the time you have, for it's precious and fleeting.
